awd_titl_txt: Methodology for Reconstructing Prior River Flow
awd_abstract_narration:
For millennia, the Nile River has played a fundamental role in the rapid growth and expansion of civilization. The intimate connection with this extensive river system has strongly influenced where the Egyptians constructed their cities, necropoleis and temples, in addition to also shaping the landscapes in which they lived, worked, died, and were buried. However, to date, there is still great uncertainty regarding the exact direction that the Nile has migrated in Egypt and whether the Nile had a single course or multiple branches that were simultaneously active in the past. While many efforts to reconstruct the ancient Nile drainage system have been conducted in previous years, they have been primarily confined to small study areas. This has led to the mapping of fragmented sections of the ancient river, however, the position and dynamic nature of the entire river channel system remains undiscovered. Such a poor understanding of the Nile history not only inhibits ability to accurately map archaeological sites, but also to understand their significance within the wider landscape. This project will help initiate a new medium for long-term national and international collaboration between scientists from different backgrounds and raise the profile of American research teams in the international archeological sphere, geospatial and environmental sciences. This research will also offer an opportunity for scientific engagement and cultural enrichment for college students based in the USA.

This project will consist in a three-year study with international colleagues to leverage the use of interdisciplinary approaches, including multisensor remote sensing together with geographical information system (GIS) modeling, historical, archeological, geomorphological, and geophysical field surveys, to reconstruct a complete map of the Nile River and many of its now defunct branches. The mapping of this ancient water system will facilitate the detection of previously undocumented sites and develop the geochronological framework for the area under investigation. Discovering the ancient Nile and having a more refined idea of where settlements were possibly located in relation to it can drastically improve our cultural heritage conservation measures and raise awareness of these sites for modern development planning. From a societal perspective, such research is important because of the wide presence of ancient sites in the proximity of unmapped paleo-river systems – both in the USA and globally – and the large human population near these sites that could affect their preservation or annihilation. The broader impacts of this project lie in the successful demonstration of the adopted methodological framework in the Nile Valley, which will allow for similar applications around other river basins worldwide and could be beneficial in protecting sites.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project utilized interdisciplinary approaches to reconstruct the ancient waterways of the Nile River. The team hypothesized that the modern-day single course of the Nile was once comprised of multiple active branches during periods of abundant rainfall, with these branches eventually silted up and shifting over time. Using satellite remote sensing, Geographic Information System (GIS) modeling geophysical ground survey, geomorphological analysis, soil coring and sampling, historical maps and archeological resources, the project aimed to identify these former Nile channels and connect their findings to existing knowledge about the locations of ancient archaeological sites.

The project developed a robust, integrated data analysis framework to help reconstruct the lost hydrological systems of the Nile floodplain. This led to two major findings: First, the detection and mapping of a previously unknown segment of a major buried ancient Nile branch, stretching more than 60 km, which once flowed near many of Egypt's pyramids between Lisht and Giza. Many of the causeways of the pyramids dating to the Old and Middle Kingdoms were found to be leading to this branch. These findings suggest that the Ahramat Branch may have played a critical role in the construction of these monuments and imply that it was concurrently operational and used as a transportation waterway for workmen and building materials to the pyramid sites. This breakthrough that was published in 2024 “The Egyptian pyramid chain was built along the now abandoned Ahramat Nile Branch” (https://www.nature.com/articles/s43247-024-01379-7) received considerable attention from the media and has an altimetric score of 2412, which puts it in the top 5% of all research outputs scored by Altmetric. The second finding from this project was around the site of Meidum Pyramid, built during the Old Kingdom more than 4,000 years ago. The project identified two ancient river courses surrounding the plateau where the Meidum Pyramid lies. This suggests that the plateau was once a ridge surrounded by waterways, or a river island, which may have influenced the stability of the pyramid. This finding, also published in 2024 (https://doi.org/10.1109/IGARSS53475.2024.10641436), might help explain the reason of the partial collapse of Meidum Pyramid and King Snefru’s decision to abandon the pyramid site and relocate his project 40 km north in Dahshur, where he built his other two pyramid complexes (the Bent and Red Pyramids). The findings from this project could help locate and uncover new archaeological sites along these buried Nile channels, providing valuable insights that will enhance our understanding of the region's history. Furthermore, the project outcomes have the potential to significantly improve ancient archaeology conservation efforts and raise awareness of these sites in the context of modern development planning.

Two activities conducted as part of this project had a significant impact on society. First, between 2022 and 2024, three conference presentations and five public lectures were given about this research. These outreach efforts aimed to educate the public about Egypt’s ancient waterscape and how it influenced the ancient Egyptians' decisions on where to build major monuments, such as pyramids and Valley Temples (ancient river ports). The second impact of this project was the training of six students (3 undergraduates, 2 M.S. students, and 1 Ph.D. candidate, many of whom come from underrepresented backgrounds) in satellite remote sensing and GIS modeling techniques for applied archaeological science. This training took place through directed independent study classes and hands-on lab sessions led by the project PIs. Additionally, the three M.S. and Ph.D. students participated in fieldwork activities during the field seasons in Egypt, where they received training in topographic surveying techniques and soil sample collection, analysis and interpretation. In addition, to promote public engagement in science and foster the development of youth science knowledge, 16 local school students, many from low socioeconomic backgrounds, participated in a half-day fieldwork activity in Egypt. The aim of these field activities was to inspire young school students by highlighting the importance of archaeology and cultural heritage, while introducing them to various STEM topics and opportunities.
